utterances: And next up, art and science with two artists who are inspired by DNA research.
One of them, Lynn Fellman, is an artist who will create a personalized portrait for you using your own DNA to track down your ancestors going back thousands of years.
You send off a tissue swab, and what you get back from her is a colorful self-portrait and a world map showing the route your distant ancestors took.
And she's here to talk about using scientific findings to enrich your art.
Welcome to the program.
Thanks, Ira.
Good to have you here.
Daniel Kohn is an artist who works with DNA and genetic research.
He was the artist in residence for two years at the Broad Institute.
That's a genetics lab.
And he set up his studio in a lab and worked along scientists, including Dr. Todd Golub, studying genetics.
And he is showing his work from the lab in New York City this June.
Welcome, Daniel, to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Hi, Ira.
Thanks for having me.
Where is your exhibit going to be shown?
It's on 24th Street at Cynthia-Reeves Gallery.
And it's starting next Thursday.
And, Lynn, you're showing today?
That's right.
Where?
I think for the most part, most minds are made up.
They know how they feel about the war, they know how they feel about the president.

And I think that last-minute blips - be it Saddam Hussein's conviction, be it John Kerry's, you know, foaming at the mouth, you know, something strange that comes at the end -I don't think that changes that many votes.
Now let's talk about some of the individual races.
We'll talk about the United States Senate for… The number to remember there is six.
If Democrats can gain six seats in the Senate, they would take control of the United States Senate.
And it's really down to just really a few states where it's truly competitive, and one state that had thought to be safely in Democratic hands was Montana.

Well, I don't know about safely, but certainly Conrad Burns, who is the lawmaker who has taken - the Republican lawmaker who has taken more money from Jack Abramoff, the convicted lobbyist, than any other member of Congress, was certainly trailing the Democratic nominee, Jon Tester.
But the latest polls show that - and the Republicans have been hammering Tester as a taxer and spender who will, you know, raise your taxes, and it seems to have made a difference.
I'm not convinced that Burns hangs on.
There has been a Democratic trend in Montana.
Tester's been a pretty good candidate, but again that race has certainly narrowed.
And so - also fascinating the other way is Virginia, the fact that that may be dead even.
You know, this was a George Allen gimme for the longest time.
Then, you know, things that he said, the missteps that he made, made it much closer.
But he has not been able, apparently, to regain his footing, and it's really, really close coming into the final days.

And New Jersey, which again some thought might be a Republican opportunity to take away a Democratic seat, that also looks like it's - at least according to the opinion polls - going to stay in Democratic hands.
In a normal year, Tom Kean, Jr., would have a very good chance of winning the seat, even though it's been over 30 years since the Republicans won a seat, a Senate seat, in New Jersey.
But the fact is Bob Menendez, the appointed Democratic incumbent, has much more money.
But most important, he has the issue of Iraq.
Iraq is extremely unpopular everywhere in the country, especially in New Jersey, and it's helping Menendez.
We're going to check in on one of those key Senate races now.
Joining us is Steve Kraske.
He hosts the program Up To Date on member station KCUR and covers politics for the Kansas City Star.
And he joins us now from a restaurant called Eggcetera in Kansas City.
Nice to have you on the program.
Hi, Neal, thanks for having me again.
And this is one of the closest Senate races in the country there, in Missouri.
Neal, absolutely breathtaking.
It's been close really throughout the entire race.
A year ago, the race was deadlocked, and as we head into the final days of this campaign, it's every bit as close as it was even 12 months ago.
And I know you've been talking with some of the patrons there at Eggcetera.
This is perfect for you, Ken.
What are they saying about this election?
Well, it's interesting.
I'm talking to two independent voters here at Eggcetera.
And one of them, Margaret Reed(ph), she's a waitress here - not a waitress here, but a waitress in a different establishment - and she was saying that the minimum wage is very important to her.
It wouldn't affect her waitressing wages directly, but Claire McCaskill, the Democrat in this Senate race, is very much four-square behind the minimum wage, and that's important to Margaret.
Jim Talent, the Republican, never really said where he stands on this issue.

Another voter here, Gloria Ewell(ph), also an independent voter - she was saying that using the word change quite a bit, as you're hearing Democrats say the word change quite a bit in the weekend news shows - that she wants to see a different direction in Iraq and hopes to see a different type of U.S.
Senate that'll give this country a different direction there.
And I just wanted to bring Ken Rudin in here.
The previous election -two years ago, Republicans thought that putting the question of gay marriage on the ballot in a lot of states would bring out their supporters.
Democrats hope this time, by putting issues like minimum wage and stem-cell research on the ballot in some states, they might do the same with their base.

Right, and Missouri's a perfect example for that, because as Steve knows, you know, the stem-cell research issues on the ballot - Claire McCaskill, the Democratic nominee, has been four-square for it from Day One, and Jim Talent has waffled on it a little bit.
Ultimately, he came out against it, but there seems to be some kind of hesitation in his dealing with that issue.
Mm hmm.
And I wanted to ask you, Steve Kraske, both sides trying to motivate their base supporters to get out and cast their ballots tomorrow.
Are they splitting left and right here?
You know, it's not clear yet exactly how they're going to split, Neal, in a race this close.
The polls don't pick up these sliver changes in a race like this.

But just to jump off of what Ken was just saying, you hear the phrase stem-cell research almost as often in Missouri these days as you hear about the war in Iraq, that voters are very much in tune with where McCaskill and Talent stand on stem-cells.
And that's a pivotal issue in this state because as Ken just said, it is a constitutional amendment ballot initiative that's gotten just huge attention here.
As much money spent in advertising on stem-cell research in Missouri as on the candidates for the U.S.
Senate themselves.
Just absolutely amazing campaign.
And I suspect almost everybody - perhaps only owners of television stations would disagree with the idea that they would like to stop seeing all this advertising.
And you hear people complaining all the time about that.

I was speaking with an undecided voter on Saturday for a poll at the Kansas City Star, and this woman was saying that her grandson sees the campaign as it's coming on TV and says: Oh Grandma, look out, they're going to start arguing again.
Okay.
Any predictions again on the McCaskill/Talent race?
Well, obviously it's still very close, the race, within the margin of error, but this morning the Gallup Organization had the poll out - has McCaskill ahead 49-45.
We're seeing a slight trend here, Neal.
Most of the polls now swaying in McCaskill's favor, although they remain well within the margin of error.
Steve Kraske, a political correspondent for the Kansas City Star and host of the program Up to Date on member station KCUR, and he joined us by phone from a diner in Kansas City.
Let's see if we get a caller on the line.
What races are you caring about?
What questions do you have with them?
If you're independent, what issues do you care about?
We'll go to Teresa(ph).
Teresa calling us from Norfolk, Virginia.
Hey.
My thing is, I care - I'm an independent voter and I really care the most about this election.
I will definitely vote for Jim Webb just because I think that Allen is too closely aligned with the president and the war.
But as well, I think that Allen really has some major race issues and that's very bothersome to me.

But what's more important that I don't understand is why there's been so much concentration on the president in a congressional election when the leadership of the Congress has, you know, things like the Mark Foley incident and nobody really says anything about that, and Tom Delay, and they don't say anything about that.
But then they're concentrating on comments that John Kerry made and, you know, who the president is and isn't supporting.
It would seem to me they need to really be careful with - especially the Mark Foley incident - because according to the way I read the law, that could even be child abuse.
And I think they really need to look at those types of issues.
Just to clarify, Jim Web, the Democrat there, and George Allen, the incumbent Republican.
Get a response, Ken Rudin, in 20 seconds?
Well, the Republicans want to change the subject.
Obviously, the Mark Foley thing has hurt them.
It certainly hurt the Republican leadership.

Some members of Congress like Deborah Price in Ohio, Tom Reynolds of New York, they may go down to defeat because of that - and obviously changing the subject is what they want to do - certainly things like John Kerry.
Teresa, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate it.
We're talking with Ken Rudin about tomorrow's midterm elections.
After the break, an update from Arizona, Tennessee and yes, from where you live if you'll give us a call.
E-mail, talk@npr.org.
This is the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
We're in the homestretch before tomorrow's midterm election.
We're taking one last look at key races around the country.
In his new Political Junkie column, Ken Rudin, NPR's political editor, makes his final calls for the most competitive Senate, gubernatorial and key House races.
You can read them if you can stand them at npr.org, it's our homepage.
Ken Rudin is here with us, of course, in Studio 3A and we - interesting, we got an e-mail last week on Ken: Why am I so abusive to you?
It's because we're good friends.
Why do you guys bicker all the time?
In jest.
Of course, you're invited to join the conversation.
If you're still undecided, what issues are you voting on?
If you have questions about the close races give us a call.
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
Paul in Mohawk Valley of New York wrote us an e-mail to ask: What do you see in New York's 24th Congressional District?
This has been, he comments, a very dirty race.
Is the 24th - I'm assuming - Well, first of all, this is a historic low point for the Republican Party in New York.
You know, George Pataki, who was governor - is governor - will leave the seat - leave it after 12 years.
Hillary Clinton overwhelmingly will win reelection in the Senate.
Eliot Spitzer, the Democrat, overwhelmingly win reelection.
And this is affecting Republicans down the ballot, especially upstate New York.
Alan Hevesi, who's running, may be in some trouble since he's been thrown over the side by his…
But if he wins the Democrat - this will be the first time since 1938 where Democrats have won every state office in New York.
That's how good the Democrats look in New York right now.
Now, Upstate New York there are a bunch of races where Republicans are running scared.
Sue Kelly just north of the New York City line - the seat that Hamilton Fish used to have.
She's in a tough race.
They call Westchester upstate because we're from New York.
I grew up in the Bronx.
Yonkers is Upstate New York for me, right.

But there are three races - there are three seats that I think the Democrats are going to pick up, and one of them is John Sweeney, who represents the eastern tier of New York - going up the Connecticut/Massachusetts border.
He's in a tough race and I think he goes out in defeat.
In the 24th, which the e-mail talks about, it's the open seat that Sherwood Boehlert is giving up - a liberal Republican - I think the Democrats take that seat too.
And I even think the Democrats have a good shot at beating Tom Reynolds in Buffalo.
Tom Reynolds is the Chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee.

If any - he's one of the few people who may be affected by the Mark Foley scandal in that he - you know, either he knew about Mark Foley in advance and didn't tell the leadership or he knew it and just tried to cover it up.

But the point is, as a part of the leadership, he may pay the - you know, pay the brunt of the blame - say that one time fast - and Reynolds may be one of those guys in the leadership who may suffer the consequences.
